title: Erdős #679: Small ω(n-k) for All k < n
description: Are there infinitely many n such that ω(n-k) < (1+ε) log k / log log k for all large k < n? The main question is OPEN; the stronger version with O(1) error is FALSE.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős posed this problem about the distribution of prime factors. The stronger version (with O(1) error) has been disproven, but the main question with (1+ε) factor remains open. Cannot be resolved by finite computation.
overview.problemStatement: Let ε > 0 and ω(n) count the number of distinct prime factors of n. Are there infinitely many n such that ω(n-k) < (1+ε) log k / log log k for all sufficiently large k < n?
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize the ω function, Hardy-Ramanujan normal order, the main conjecture, the disproven stronger version, the Ω variant, special cases (powers of 2, primorials), lower bounds, and density considerations.
keyInsights: The stronger version with O(1) error is FALSE
For all large n, ∃ k: ω(n-k) ≥ log k/log log k + c(log k)/(log log k)²
Hardy-Ramanujan: ω(n) ~ log log n for almost all n
The Ω variant uses threshold log₂ k
Cannot be resolved by finite computation

sections.title: Hardy-Ramanujan Bound
sections.summary: Normal order of ω(n) is log log n

sections.title: Key Dichotomy
sections.summary: Either infinitely many exist or uniform lower bound

conclusion.summary: This formalization captures Erdős Problem #679 on small ω(n-k) values. The main question is OPEN but the stronger version with O(1) error has been disproven. The problem cannot be resolved by finite computation.
conclusion.implications: Understanding when all n-k have small prime factor counts connects to the distribution of smooth numbers and the Hardy-Ramanujan theorem on normal orders.
openQuestions: Does the main conjecture hold for any ε > 0?
What is the density of special n if they exist?
What is the analogous answer for Ω?
